explanation:
To determine whether this function violates the MISRA rule that pointers should be to const-qualified types whenever possible, the analysis must know the exact parameter types (including const qualification) and the provenance/types of the data passed. Specifically:

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (declaration/prototype): Required to know the type of its second parameter (e.g. const void * vs void * or char *). Passing page_content (a const char[] local) to a non-const parameter would be a const-qualification / conversion issue under MISRA.

- MHD_add_response_header (declaration/prototype): Needed to check the const qualification of the header and value parameters (e.g. const char * vs char *). The code passes string literals / constants; the function prototype determines whether those are compatible without removing const.

- MHD_queue_response (declaration/prototype): Needed to confirm the types of its parameters (especially the struct MHD_Response * parameter) to see whether a const qualifier is expected/required when passing resp.

- MHD_destroy_response (declaration/prototype): Needed to see whether it takes a const or non-const pointer; although destruction typically takes a non-const pointer, the prototype is required for a complete const-qualification assessment.

- MAIN_PAGE (macro/definition): The initializer for page_content; its type (string literal or other expression) affects whether page_content is indeed const data and whether any implicit conversions occur.

- MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_TYPE (macro/definition): The header identifier passed to MHD_add_response_header — whether this symbol is a const char * or a non-const char * matters for const-qualification checks.

- struct MHD_Response (type definition): The prototype parameter types may reference this type; having its definition helps verify whether pointers to it should be const in the called APIs.

- struct MHD_Connection (type definition): Needed to validate the type passed to MHD_queue_response and whether any constness expectations apply.

Provide these declarations/definitions to the next analyzer so it can determine whether any arguments require/removal of const qualifiers and thus whether the target function violates the MISRA rule.
